article.headline: (21) GONZAGA 90, DENVER 58
article.story: SPOKANE, Wash. (AP) -- Cory Violette and the Gonzaga Bulldogs ran away from Denver in the second half. Denver used good shooting to take an early lead, but key players got into foul trouble and No. 16 Gonzaga's depth eventually wore the Pioneers down en route to a 90-58 victory Monday night. "We kept going at them the whole time," said Violette, who scored 16 points. "It's not just depth but size. Teams have to deal with us running, and then we get under the basket." Gonzaga (2-1) limited Denver to seven field goals and outscored the Pioneers 45-23 in the second half to coast to victory. Ronny Turiaf scored 21 points, while Blake Stepp added 14 points and seven assists. Freshman Adam Morrison had 12 points and 12 rebounds in just 21 minutes. It was the season opener for Denver, which charged to a 21-12 lead behind four 3-pointers by Erik Benzel. But Benzel, fellow guard Rodney Billups and forward Zeljko Zupic all got into foul trouble as Gonzaga battled back. Stepp's steal and lay-up tied the score at 28-all with 6:35 left in the first. With Benzel and Billups, brother of Chauncey Billups, on the bench, Gonzaga closed with a 12-3 run for a 45-35 halftime lead. Gonzaga led 47-41 early in the second when Tony Skinner's 3-pointer initiated a 23-6 run that buried the Pioneers. Freshmen Morrison (six points) and Sean Mallon (four points) fueled the run as Gonzaga moved out to a 65-45 lead. "With our depth you can physically wear people down," Gonzaga coach Mark Few said. Denver coach Terry Carroll said his team missed the play of its guards in the second half, particularly Billups. "We missed Billups' ability to get us into our offense," Carroll said. Gonzaga pulled down 18 offensive rebounds in the game and forced Denver into 19 turnovers, while committing only nine. "They really gave us a lesson on the glass," Carroll said. "I wouldn't be surprised if they do what they do every year and go back to the tournament," Billups said. Zupic and Benzel led Denver with 13 points each. The 32-point loss was Denver's worst since an 85-51 drubbing by Colorado State in 2000. Gonzaga played without heralded newcomer Errol Knight, who has a sprained ankle. It wasn't clear if Knight will be ready to play against Georgia on Saturday, Few said. He was pleased with Gonzaga's second half defense, and a patient offense that saw 10 players score. Most surprising is Morrison, a true freshman from Spokane who has scored in double figures all three games of his college career. "Adam really knows how to score," Few said. Few acknowledged that with so many player combinations, the Bulldogs are still sorting out how to play with each other. "We're still a team trying out roles," Few said. One player who is sure of his place is Stepp, last year's West Coast Conference player of the year. With his team in trouble early, Stepp scored 14 points in the first half. He did not score in the second, preferring to dish out assists. "In the first half he kept us in it," Few said. "Then he was more than happy to distribute the ball in the second half. "That's what you need out of your senior leader."
